meta.title: Phase 2.1 Hero Section Redesign - Rule of 3 Copywriting

context.problem: Current hero section only emphasizes 'marketplace' with generic messaging. Users don't understand the THREE core value drivers of the site.
context.solution: Redesign hero using 'Rule of 3' copywriting principle. Present all three value propositions clearly in hero so users immediately understand what they get.
context.impact: Users see value instantly â†’ faster conversion â†’ more creator signups â†’ more marketplace activity

rule_of_three.definition: The Rule of 3 in copywriting states that things are more memorable, satisfying, and effective when presented in groups of three. Examples: 'Life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness' / 'Stop, look, listen' / 'Fast, cheap, good (pick two)'
rule_of_three.why_it_works: Three items feel complete. Two feels incomplete. Four feels cluttered. Three is the 'Goldilocks' of persuasive messaging.
rule_of_three.how_we_apply_it: Present three distinct value propositions (not variations of the same thing) in hero section.

questions.q1: Why these three values and not others?
questions.a1: These are the core business drivers: 1) Users need tools (marketplace), 2) Creators want revenue (commission), 3) People want community (networking). No other value proposition matters if these three aren't clear.

q2: What if users don't click the card buttons?
a2: That's fine - the main CTAs (Browse All Tools, List Resource) are still below. Cards provide additional paths and show the three value props clearly. Main CTAs are primary.
q3: Isn't this adding more to the page?
a3: Yes, but it's REPLACING repetitive content (CTASection below). Net result: Hero gets richer, page overall gets simpler.
